citation.article-title: Thalassobaculum salexigens sp. nov., a new member of the family Rhodospirillaceae from the NW Mediterranean Sea, and emended description of the genus Thalassobaculum
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thalassobaculum salexigens sp. nov.
Thalassobaculum salexigens (sa.lex′i.gens. L. n. sal salis salt, seawater; L. v. exigo to demand; N.L. part. adj. salexigens seawater-demanding).
Forms cream colonies on marine agar medium.
Major fatty acids are: C18 : 1ω7c, C17 : 0, C16 : 0 and C16 : 1ω7c.
Growth occurs at 15–37 °C (optimum 30 °C), at pH 5.0–10.0 (optimum 8.0) and over a salinity range of 7–54 g l−1 (optimum 34–40 g l−1).
Catalase and oxidase tests are positive.
Positive reactions with Biolog GN2 plates are obtained for arabitol, erythritol, fructose, fucose, glucose, lactose, lactulose, mannitol, γ-hydroxybutyrate and propionate.
Positive reactions are obtained for leucine arylamidase and valine arylamidase enzymic activities with the API ZYM kit.
The type strain, CZ41_10aT (=DSM 19539T=CIP 109064T=MOLA 84T), was isolated from the water column in the bay of Banyuls-sur-Mer (4 ° 29′ N ° 08′ E).
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 65 mol%.
